                              <b:includable id='threaded_comment_js' var='post'>
                                <script async='async' expr:src='data:post.commentSrc' type='text/javascript'/>
                                <script type='text/javascript'>
                                  (function() {
                                    var items = <data:post.commentJso/>;
                                    var msgs = <data:post.commentMsgs/>;
                                    var config = <data:post.commentConfig/>;
                                    // <![CDATA[
                                    var cursor = null;
                                    if (items && items.length > 0) {
                                      cursor = parseInt(items[items.length - 1].timestamp) + 1;
                                    }
                                    var bodyFromEntry = function(entry) {
                                      if (entry.gd$extendedProperty) {
                                        for (var k in entry.gd$extendedProperty) {
                                          if (entry.gd$extendedProperty[k].name == 'blogger.contentRemoved') {
                                            return '<span class="deleted-comment">' + entry.content.$t + '</span>';
                                          }
                                        }
                                      }
                                      return entry.content.$t;
                                    }
                                    var parse = function(data) {
                                      cursor = null;
                                      var comments = [];
                                      if (data && data.feed && data.feed.entry) {
                                        for (var i = 0, entry; entry = data.feed.entry[i]; i++) {
                                          var comment = {};
                                          // comment ID, parsed out of the original id format
                                          var id = /blog-(\d+).post-(\d+)/.exec(entry.id.$t);
                                          comment.id = id ? id[2] : null;
                                          comment.body = bodyFromEntry(entry);
                                          comment.timestamp = Date.parse(entry.published.$t) + '';
                                          if (entry.author && entry.author.constructor === Array) {
                                            var auth = entry.author[0];
                                            if (auth) {
                                              comment.author = {
                                                name: (auth.name ? auth.name.$t : undefined),
                                                profileUrl: (auth.uri ? auth.uri.$t : undefined),
                                                avatarUrl: (auth.gd$image ? auth.gd$image.src : undefined)
                                              };
                                            }
                                          }
                                          if (entry.link) {
                                            if (entry.link[2]) {
                                              comment.link = comment.permalink = entry.link[2].href;
                                            }
                                            if (entry.link[3]) {
                                              var pid = /.*comments\/default\/(\d+)\?.*/.exec(entry.link[3].href);
                                              if (pid && pid[1]) {
                                                comment.parentId = pid[1];
                                              }
                                            }
                                          }
                                          comment.deleteclass = 'item-control blog-admin';
                                          if (entry.gd$extendedProperty) {
                                            for (var k in entry.gd$extendedProperty) {
                                              if (entry.gd$extendedProperty[k].name == 'blogger.itemClass') {
                                                comment.deleteclass += ' ' + entry.gd$extendedProperty[k].value;
                                              } else if (entry.gd$extendedProperty[k].name == 'blogger.displayTime') {
                                                comment.displayTime = entry.gd$extendedProperty[k].value;
                                              }
                                            }
                                          }
                                          comments.push(comment);
                                        }
                                      }
                                      return comments;
                                    };
                                    var paginator = function(callback) {
                                      if (hasMore()) {
                                        var url = config.feed + '?alt=json&v=2&orderby=published&reverse=false&max-results=50';
                                        if (cursor) {
                                          url += '&published-min=' + new Date(cursor).toISOString();
                                        }
                                        window.bloggercomments = function(data) {
                                          var parsed = parse(data);
                                          cursor = parsed.length < 50 ? null
                                          : parseInt(parsed[parsed.length - 1].timestamp) + 1
                                          callback(parsed);
                                          window.bloggercomments = null;
                                        }
                                        url += '&callback=bloggercomments';
                                        var script = document.createElement('script');
                                        script.type = 'text/javascript';
                                        script.src = url;
                                        document.getElementsByTagName('head')[0].appendChild(script);
                                      }
                                    };
                                    var hasMore = function() {
                                      return !!cursor;
                                    };
                                    var getMeta = function(key, comment) {
                                      if ('iswriter' == key) {
                                        var matches = !!comment.author
                                        && comment.author.name == config.authorName
                                        && comment.author.profileUrl == config.authorUrl;
                                        return matches ? 'true' : '';
                                      } else if ('deletelink' == key) {
                                        return config.baseUri + '/delete-comment.g?blogID='
                                        + config.blogId + '&postID=' + comment.id;
                                      } else if ('deleteclass' == key) {
                                        return comment.deleteclass;
                                      }
                                      return '';
                                    };
                                    var replybox = null;
                                    var replyUrlParts = null;
                                    var replyParent = undefined;
                                    var onReply = function(commentId, domId) {
                                      if (replybox == null) {
                                        // lazily cache replybox, and adjust to suit this style:
                                        replybox = document.getElementById('comment-editor');
                                        if (replybox != null) {
                                          replybox.height = '250px';
                                          replybox.style.display = 'block';
                                          replyUrlParts = replybox.src.split('#');
                                        }
                                      }
                                      if (replybox && (commentId !== replyParent)) {
                                        document.getElementById(domId).insertBefore(replybox, null);
                                        replybox.src = replyUrlParts[0]
                                        + (commentId ? '&parentID=' + commentId : '')
                                        + '#' + replyUrlParts[1];
                                        replyParent = commentId;
                                      }
                                    };
                                    var hash = (window.location.hash || '#').substring(1);
                                    var startThread, targetComment;
                                    if (/^comment-form_/.test(hash)) {
                                      startThread = hash.substring('comment-form_'.length);
                                    } else if (/^c[0-9]+$/.test(hash)) {
                                      targetComment = hash.substring(1);
                                    }
                                    // Configure commenting API:
                                    var configJso = {
                                      'maxDepth': config.maxThreadDepth
                                    };
                                    var provider = {
                                      'id': config.postId,
                                      'data': items,
                                      'loadNext': paginator,
                                      'hasMore': hasMore,
                                      'getMeta': getMeta,
                                      'onReply': onReply,
                                      'rendered': true,
                                      'initComment': targetComment,
                                      'initReplyThread': startThread,
                                      'config': configJso,
                                      'messages': msgs
                                    };
                                    var render = function() {
                                      if (window.goog && window.goog.comments) {
                                        var holder = document.getElementById('comment-holder');
                                        window.goog.comments.render(holder, provider);
                                      }
                                    };
                                    // render now, or queue to render when library loads:
                                    if (window.goog && window.goog.comments) {
                                      render();
                                    } else {
                                      window.goog = window.goog || {};
                                      window.goog.comments = window.goog.comments || {};
                                      window.goog.comments.loadQueue = window.goog.comments.loadQueue || [];
                                      window.goog.comments.loadQueue.push(render);
                                    }
                                  })();
                                  // ]]>
                                </script>
                              </b:includable>
                              <b:includable id='threaded_comments' var='post'>

                                  <h4>

<b:section-contents id='sidebar-right-1'>
  <b:widget id='HTML2' locked='false' title='About Kurt' type='HTML'>
    <b:widget-settings>
      <b:widget-setting name='content'><div class="headshot"></div>

<p>Kurt Duffeck is not just a REALTOR but a licensed Broker Associate with over 17 years of expertise in Real Estate Marketing, Sales, Negotiating and Investing. Kurt is the founder of Anew Real Estate Crew.</p>


<p>The Anew Real Estate Crew is your one-stop-shop in the AUSTIN, TX Metro for all of your family's real estate Buying & Selling needs. Through our local referral network we track both, listings "not yet on the market" and all Active & Sold MLS properties. Start with our state-of-the-art home search website and view all Austin, TX Metro Homes For Sale - search by neighborhood, zip, or map. - or request a free, no-obligation estimate of your home's value. We've got all the local resources you'll need for the planning of your family's move - and on through the many years of home ownership.<p>
<p>To say it simply, We put our heart into it! Start Right. Start Anew. Kurt Duffeck and the Anew Real Estate Crew are proud to be a part of EXP Realty LLC. An agent-owned, cloud-based real estate firm that's streamlining and changing the real estate industry by helping top real estate agents do their jobs better. Agents and brokers at EXP work together to build businesses, enhance brands, increase profitability, reduce overhead and risk, and achieve bold career and life goals, all while establishing a direct ownership interest in EXP Realty International Corporation as a shareholder and partner. To learn more about why we chose EXP - be sure to call today!</p>

<strong>Start Right. Start ANEW!</strong>

});

entry.title: How Can We Help You Achieve Your Real Estate Dreams?
entry.content:
Are you looking to buy, sell, or rent a home? No matter what your real estate dreams are, we can help.

Want to sell your Austin Home? Get a FREE home value report
Want to buy an Austin Home? Search all homes for sale


Today I wanted to reach out to you and see what we can do to help you with your dreams of moving.

I know that moving can seem like an overwhelming task. Whether you’re renting or buying a new place, gearing up for a move is a big deal.

However, I can help you through this process.

If you are buying a home, my services are free. I know what it takes to coordinate a big move. I can even help you sell your current home and move at the same time; a lot of buyers need to sell before they can buy another property.

I have developed some proven strategies over the past 17 years that will help you get top dollar for your home.
I have developed proven strategies to help you get top dollar for your home.
Even if you are renting in today’s market, I can help you out. Rentals are pretty hard to come by these days, unless you are looking for an apartment. If you’re looking for a smaller home to rent, that market is as hot as the sales market, and those homes go pretty quickly.

We also have a great network of real estate agents around the country, so we can help you whether you are moving locally or out of the state.

If you happen to know of anyone or you yourself are thinking of moving, just give us a call. We would be happy to help you!

link.title: How Can We Help You Achieve Your Real Estate Dreams?

entry.title: What's Going on in Our Market Today?
entry.content:
Now that we’re halfway through the year, it’s time for a market update.

Want to sell your Austin Home? Get a FREE home value report
Want to buy an Austin Home? Search all homes for sale


Today, I’m out at the Play Shop, where I’ve just found some real estate statistics for our Austin, Texas area for the month of June.

Here in Austin, the median home price has gone up 4% year over year from last June. The price that homes are selling for, on average, is now $303,000.

Remember to think of this number as a halfway point—half of homes will sell above this price, and half will sell below.
We’re seeing a few numbers that have gone up from this time last year.
In fact, we’re seeing a few numbers that have gone up from this time last year.

Today, our average days on market is 16 days—meaning that number is up 14% from what we saw this time last year.

Total sales, though, are down 3% from last year—$3,656 for the month of June. But, the average price per square foot is currently $182, and some new builders are doing even better than that.

If you have any other questions or want more information, feel free to give me a call or send me an email. I look forward to hearing from you soon.

link.title: What's Going on in Our Market Today?

entry.title: How to Get Your Home Sold If You Have a Pet
entry.content:
If you have a pet and you're looking to sell your home, then read on for some helpful advice.

Want to sell your Austin Home? Get a FREE home value report
Want to buy an Austin Home? Search all homes for sale


The good news is, many homebuyers are looking for a pet-friendly home.

Two out of three of us have a pet, and 61% of pet owners say they have trouble finding a home that is a good match for their pet.

In fact, a recent survey estimates that 31% of animal owners frequently don't put in an offer because a home would not suit their pet.

This means that if your home is a good match for a pet, it will be attractive to a large pool of dedicated animal owners.

On the other hand, 67% of Realtors also estimate that actually having a pet in your home can make it harder for you to sell.

So what can you do? Here are three things I typically recommend:

1. Repair any damage

Floors, walls, doors, the yard — these are some typical areas that pets love to chew, scratch, and dig up.

Repairing this damage is an investment that will pay for itself many times over in terms of a higher selling price.
Pet owners are less sensitive to odors in their home than prospective buyers are.
2. Get a professional to remove pet odors

Many pet owners are less sensitive to odors in their home than prospective buyers will be. 
That's why you should hire a professional cleaning crew to clean any carpets, rugs, or upholstery that have absorbed pet odors.

Once you're done with the cleaning, ask a friend or your Realtor for a sniff assessment to make sure the job is really complete.

3. Take your pet out during showings

Some people are afraid of animals. Others are allergic. And regardless of the time, money, and effort you've put in to clean and repair your home, many buyers will be prejudiced by knowing that a pet currently lives there.

That's why I recommend taking your pet out during showings and also removing any pet objects such as toys, food bowls, or scratching posts.

By following these three simple guidelines, you will be able to sell your home for top dollar, whether the buyer is a pet owner or not.

And in case you have any questions or concerns about preparing your home for a sale, give me a call. I’m here to help.

link.title: How to Get Your Home Sold If You Have a Pet

entry.title: What Zillow’s Day in Court Says About Their Zestimate
entry.content:
Zillow is being sued by a disgruntled homeowner, and the reason why will tell you everything you need to know about their Zestimates.

Want to sell your Austin Home? Get a FREE home value report
Want to buy an Austin Home? Search all homes for sale


In case you haven’t heard, a recent lawsuit was filed against Zillow by an Illinois homeowner and it’s causing ripples in the real estate industry. How does this affect you?

First, let me start by saying I’m not here to hate on Zillow like so many other agents do. I actually love Zillow, and many of the clients I have today first got in contact with me after reading my reviews on Zillow. I think they do a great job of mapping out neighborhoods and providing information about certain areas, school districts, etc.

Now, the homeowner in this lawsuit claims her home is valued at $626,000, but Zillow values it at $562,000, which is a $64,000 difference. This woman feels that the typical buyer will feel that her home is worth less because of its Zestimate. Zillow responded by saying that a Zestimate is just a starting point to determine value, and it’s not an official appraisal.

Even well-known real estate mogul Barbara Corcoran of ABC’s “Shark Tank” chimed in on the matter on “Good Morning America,” which you can watch here.

When you start your online home search, Zillow is a website you’ll likely land on because they do a great job capturing nearly 64% of all real estate-related web traffic. Is it a good start for determining the value of your home, though?

Barbara Corcoran says that it’s a starting point, but not a reliable starting point, which I agree with.
Zillow is a starting point for home value, but not a reliable starting point.
You may not know this, but Zillow admits that its fault factor is around 5.6%. That means that less than half of the values in a given area are less than that fault factor percentage and half are even further off. To put that into perspective, on a $250,000 house, that’s a $14,000 difference one way or the other.

In Texas, Zillow doesn’t even offer a percentage of error because we’re a non-disclosure state, meaning our sales prices aren’t publicly disclosed at closing. You need to hire a professional to get that information.

The good news is that Zillow CEO Spencer Rascoff is opening up their platform and offering a $1 million prize to any person or team who can improve their algorithm. I encourage you to take advantage of this opportunity if you think you can do so. In the meantime, if you really want to know the value of your home, call me. My team and I can put our experience of selling hundreds of homes over the years to good use so you can sell your home for the most money in the shortest amount of time.

If you have any questions about this or any other real estate topic, please don’t hesitate to reach out to me. I look forward to helping you.

link.title: What Zillow’s Day in Court Says About Their Zestimate

entry.content: “I was looking one night on the internet, at Zillow, and liked several of the houses and my wife, recently we discovered that she is not going to be able to do everything that she’s done before in her life. She’s had several brain surgeries and is now handicapped because of that. I put in all of the information that we were looking for, and I mean very specific in some areas. I entered it into the system and received a phone call back from Kurt either the next day or a few days later. We worked together from August 2016 to current. He put me in touch with someone who could sell our home in San Antonio and I wasn’t real happy with the conversations we had. So Kurt said, well you know what, have you ever considered doing an online sale, like an auction? I said, no I hadn’t. And he said well I can do that for you if you’re interested. I said absolutely. He even worked with my family in the process because I had family as renters, helping them to find another place. We went down to San Antonio for the closing and from the time we started the conversation about selling to the time that we closed on the house I think was four weeks. Even just at the inception of the conversation, just saying, hey Kurt what do you think about you being the agent for the house in San Antonio? And in four weeks had it sold. That’s it! We are also, in the midst of all of that, we are building a home. The truth of the matter was I was interested in unloading the house and so it wasn’t that I had to have $10,000 above asking price, but we got so close to my asking price that it’s not even funny. Family is important to him, he’s a pretty easy going guy and he bent over backwards to help me. He didn’t push one particular thing over another. When it came to the lender that we were using he made a suggestion to us and we tried that lender, but in the end, when it came down to being able to have more money at closing for us from another lender, we went with that lender and he was fully behind it.”

entry.title: What’s the Difference Between an Appraisal and an Inspection?
entry.content:
How are home inspections and appraisals different? Melanie Taliaferro from SWBC Mortgage joins me to explain.

Want to sell your Austin Home? Get a FREE home value report
Want to buy an Austin Home? Search all homes for sale



What is the difference between an appraisal and an inspection? Melanie Taliaferro from SWBC Mortgage joins me today to explain this a little more fully.

When you make an offer on a house, there is something called the ‘option period.’ During that time, you have the opportunity to do your due diligence as a buyer. You should always hire a licensed home inspector to come in and do an inspection on the property.

A licensed home inspector will check everything from the roof to the foundation. If there is a major issue with your air conditioner, roof, or any other system in the house, then the home inspector may recommend that you get a specialist’s opinion. The inspector will also give you a 50-page report of everything they found in the home.

Some people use the terms ‘inspection’ and ‘appraisal’ interchangeably, which makes things confusing. However, the appraisal is very different from the home inspection. After you order the home inspection and decide you want to move forward with the purchase, the lender will require you to order an appraisal. This happens after the option period because you have completed your due diligence and decided that you want to buy the home.
The lender will order the appraisal after the option period has ended.
During the appraisal, a licensed appraiser will come out to inspect the property. They won’t do a true, detailed inspection like the home inspector did. The appraiser is just there to provide an opinion of the value of the property.

The appraiser will pull comparable sales of similar homes within a half-mile radius from the last six months to see if the purchase price matches the market value of the home. The appraiser looks for similar-sized homes with similar amenities in order to make that decision. The appraiser will then tell the lender whether or not the market value of the home matches the purchase price you and the seller have already agreed upon.

The appraiser may also recommend certain repairs. If something comes up in the appraisal affecting the safety or livability of the property, then the appraisal will be subject to repairs.

Ultimately, although appraisals and inspections are very similar, the appraisal is the biggest piece of our property approval process. The main difference is that the inspection is part of the buyer’s due diligence while the appraisal has more to do with the lending side, getting a loan, and making sure that the investment is worth its value.

If you have any questions about appraisals or the lending side of buying a home, you can reach Melanie at 512-400-0342 or at Melanie@TheTaliaFerroTeam.com. As always, if you have any real estate questions, please don’t hesitate to reach out to me. I would be happy to help you!

link.title: What’s the Difference Between an Appraisal and an Inspection?

entry.title: The Difference Between Being Pre-Approved and Pre-Qualified
entry.content:
What is the difference between being pre-approved and pre-qualified for a mortgage? Melanie Taliaferro from SWBC Mortgage is here to answer that today. 

Want to sell your Austin Home? Get a FREE home value report
Want to buy an Austin Home? Search all homes for sale



Today I’m joined by Melanie Taliaferro from SWBC mortgage to answer the question, “What is the difference between being pre-approved and pre-qualified?”

People use the terms pre-approved and pre-qualified interchangeably when it comes to mortgages, but there is definitely a difference.

A pre-qualification can be as little as a verbal conversation with a borrower in which the lender asks about income and credit then tells the borrower based on their answers that they are pre-qualified for a home loan. That confirmation can be verbal or in writing, and the strength of a pre-qualification can range.

A true pre-approval means that a lender has not only gotten a written loan application, but has also pulled your credit report and evaluated your income and assets to get an overview of your whole financial picture before issuing a pre-approval letter. Having a pre-approval letter, then, will make your offer much stronger and put you in a position to beat out someone who might have only been pre-qualified.
A pre-approval letter will always make your offer stronger.
If you have any questions for Melanie, you can give her a call at 512-825-1196. As always, if you have any questions for me, feel free to give me a call or send me an email. I’m always happy to help!

link.title: The Difference Between Being Pre-Approved and Pre-Qualified

entry.title: Why Did Your Mortgage Payment Suddenly Increase?
entry.content:
Has your mortgage payment gone up recently? If you don’t know why, this might be the reason.


Want to sell your Austin Home? Get a FREE home value report

Want to buy an Austin Home? Search all homes for sale


Are you curious why your mortgage payment is going up this time of year? Today I’m joined by Melanie Taliaferro to help shed some light on this subject.

According to her, it’s important to remember that property taxes change every year, especially in the Austin area with values increasing as they are. That amount gets paid at the end of each year. When it’s paid out, there may or may not be enough money in your escrow account to cover it. Once it is paid, the mortgage company may realize there’s not enough money to pay the bill. They then have to increase the monthly payment in order to cover the deficit.

Because you just paid taxes for a property you lived in the whole year, there’s a shortage that needs to be covered in addition to what has to be planned for the following year. That can almost result a double increase for some people. The best thing you can do is take your most recent mortgage statement and send it to a mortgage professional so they can help you decode it.
Keep a close eye on your monthly mortgage statement.
Also, pay special attention to your county value assessment, which you’ll typically receive in April or May. That will tell you what your projected taxable value on your property is for that year. That’s something a mortgage professional can look at and adjust your payment proactively if it needs to be increased.

This can be a frustrating topic, so if you have any more concerns, you can reach Melanie by phone at (512) 400-0342 or email her at Melanie@thetaliaferroteam.com.

If you have any other questions, please feel free to reach out to me. I’d be happy to help!

link.title: Why Did Your Mortgage Payment Suddenly Increase?

entry.title: Why Are the Holidays a Good Time to Sell?
entry.content:
Contrary to what you may have heard, the holiday season is actually a great time to sell your house. Why? I have four reasons to share with you today.

Want to sell your Austin Home? Get a FREE home value report
Want to buy an Austin Home? Search all homes for sale


Are the holidays a good time to sell your house? Absolutely. Let me give you a few reasons why:
 
1. Interest rates are still low. This means there are still many buyers out shopping for homes.
 
2. There are fewer homes on the market this time of year than there are during the peak season. Right now, sellers can beat a wave of competition that will hit the market in the springtime. With so few homes on the market right now, you can beat that competition.
 
“
Homes decorated for the holidays show better.

”
3. Homes decorated for the holidays show better. Christmas decorations and lights give a home that cozy feel, and they show better because of it.
 
4. Buyers are more serious. You may have fewer buyers come to your home overall, but the buyers who do come through will be much more serious about buying. They usually want to get a deal done before Christmas or before the new year.
 
Here in Austin, the market is strong, so it's still an ideal time to get your home on the market. If you're thinking about selling or buying a house this season, give me a call or send me an email soon. I'd be happy to help you.

link.title: Why Are the Holidays a Good Time to Sell?

entry.title: How to Know What to Offer on a Home
entry.content:
When I’m sitting down with a client helping them write an offer on a home in a multiple offer situation, they always ask me the same question: “Kurt, how much should I offer?”

In order to know what a fair price is, you’ll need to sit down with your own agent and look at the comparable home sales. Depending on the neighborhood in question, you may want to look back as far as six to 12 months. Try to compare properties in an “apples to apples” sense. For example, you don’t want to be comparing two-story homes with single-story homes, as single-story homes typically have a higher average price per square foot.
“
Compare properties in an “apples to apples” sense.

”

From there, your agent should be able to guide you through the stats to figure out what a fair, competitive price would be. It’s important to remember, though, that sometimes numbers on paper don’t mean a whole lot. Homes tend to speak to people’s emotions above all else. It wouldn’t hurt to formulate a strategy to appeal to these emotions, too, so you can win the house you want.

By the way, our new real estate crew is hiring! We’re currently looking for part-time administrative help and, as always, some fantastic buyer’s agents. If you or anyone you know would be interested, don’t hesitate to reach out to us.

If you have any more questions about multiple offer situations or real estate in general, give me a call or send me an email. I look forward to helping you in any way I can.

entry.title: What’s Happening in the Austin Metro?
entry.content:
With lots of people moving into the Austin metro, the market is still moving fast. With the summer season over, home builders are looking to sell off inventory.

Want to buy an Austin Home? Search all homes for sale

It’s been a very busy summer in our market and there are a lot of people moving to the Austin metro area.

In areas like Cedar Park and Williamson County, we’re seeing a massive amount of new construction happening as well. Many of the builders are offering fantastic incentives to purchase their homes, so if you’ve ever thought about buying a brand-new home, now is the time.

The back-to-school selling season is over, so builders really want to get the inventory that didn’t sell during that time off the books as the end of the year approaches.
 
In our market, we’ve seen average home sale volume go down for the second straight month, according to the Austin Board of Realtors. However, the average median sales price continues to climb. Across the Austin metro, the median sales price is $285,000, with the median price in Williamson right around $265,000.

“
If you’ve ever thought about buying new construction, now is the time.

”

As we end the year, I expect to see the market soften up just a little bit. Interest rates are still very low, so we’re still going to see a lot of people moving here and buying a home, and at the same time, it looks like inventory is building.

entry.title: How Much Will Your Down Payment Cost?
entry.content:
One question I get asked all the time is, “How much money do I need as a down payment if I’m going to buy a home?” Basically, you have two different options:

The first is to go online and check. The Internet features an array of different websites that function as mortgage calculators. One of my favorites is SmartAssets.com, where you can scroll through the site quickly and let them know what kind of loan you’re looking to apply for and it will give you a quick approximation of how much money you need to put down.

“
There are many different loans out there.

”

For a more accurate estimate, your second option is getting in touch with a mortgage professional. There are many different loans out there. Depending on your financial situation and your credit, it might be difficult to ascertain which one works best for you. Additionally, it’s important to keep closing costs in mind, as they will be a part of your initial down payment when buying a home.

If you have any further questions about down payments or real estate in general, feel free to give me a call or shoot me an email. I look forward to helping you in any way that I can.

link.title: How Much Will Your Down Payment Cost?

entry.title: How Is the Austin Real Estate Market Performing this Spring?
entry.content:
Want to sell your Austin Home? Get a FREE home value report
Want to buy an Austin Home? Search all homes for sale

I know it might be hard to believe, but the Austin real estate market actually performed better in 2016 than it did in 2015. Our market continues to be white-hot.

The median sales price for single family homes was $269k, which is an 8% increase from last year. Sales are also up by 3%, and the average number of days on the market has increased and now stands at 62 days. However, if your home is priced right and in good condition, it’s probably going to sell within a few days.


This is because our inventory is still so low. We only have 2.1 months of homes available, so this market is heavily favoring home sellers. A balanced market would have six months of supply, so we hardly have any homes to sell! This means that sellers are getting great prices for their homes.

This is all fantastic news for the Austin real estate market. Buyers may be fighting an uphill battle, but interest rates are low and I have some strategies that can help you to win your dream home.

If you’re looking to enter the Austin real estate market, please don’t hesitate to contact me!

entry.title: How Long Does It Take to Close on a Home in Austin?
entry.content:
Want to sell your Austin Home? Get a FREE home value report
Want to buy an Austin Home? Search all homes for sale


One of my clients recently asked me how long it takes to close on a home in Austin. This is a good question, because timing is very important to the real estate process. 

If you take out a mortgage loan, you can expect it to take at least 45 days in total for that to close. Some of the best lenders in town may be able to get that done in 30 days, but I would count on having it take a little longer. Recent TRID changes have slowed the process a little bit, but these new kinks should be worked out of the process shortly as professionals in the industry adjust to these changes.
  

If you’re a cash buyer you can expect to close in as little as two weeks.

If you need a good lender to speed up this process, or if you’d like help selling your Austin home this spring, please don’t hesitate to reach out to me!

entry.title: Will Waiting to Sell Your Austin Home Cost You Down the Road?
entry.content:
Want to sell your Austin Home? Get a FREE home value report
Want to buy an Austin Home? Search all homes for sale


Although it's still winter here in Austin, the weather has been fantastic and the market has been busy.

There are very few homes on the market right now. There's a lot of investment money moving into the Austin metro area, so we're seeing first-time buyers, move-up buyers, and investors all competing for the same buyers. As a result, multiple offer situations are happening on a regular basis. In fact, homes below $300,000 are being viewed the day they’re listed and, more often than not, bidding wars break out shortly after.

In the $500,000 and above price range, there is a whole lot more to choose from. This is especially true of some of the areas in Williamson County. There is a lot of competition among home builders in that area, which means that you can get really good incentives packages, such as upgrades or having your closing costs paid for, in addition to the great prices they’re offering. This makes now a great time to buy in new construction!


The combination of low interest rates and low inventory makes now a great time to both sell and buy. Prices have come up so much here in Austin that now might be a great time to take a little bit off the top, especially if you’re looking at your home as an investment. It looks like appreciation will be slowing down soon -- as interest rates continue their rise, there is reason to believe that home prices will be too by the end of this summer.
 
If you list your home soon, you’re probably going to receive multiple offers, especially if your home is clean and move-in ready. On the buyer side, it takes a lot of strategy and positioning in order to accomplish your moving goals. Your odds of success really depend on the area and the price point you’re shopping in.

If you have any questions about the state of the Austin real estate market, or if you would like our assistance, please don’t hesitate to reach out to us! We would love to help you make the most of the current market!

entry.title: Prepare Your Home for the Holidays with these Decorating Tips!
entry.content:
Want to sell your Austin Home? Get a FREE home value report
Want to buy an Austin Home? Search all homes for sale

The holidays are approaching. Today, we thought we'd do something a little different and share this festive video on holiday decorating tips from HGTV. Designer Angelo Surmelis shares several great ideas to spread holiday cheer throughout the home. Here are some of our favorites.

  1. Pay attention to the mantle. If you don't have some already, buy some kind of garland to drape over the mantle. Next, use leftover ornaments and candles to add light and texture. When choosing ornaments and candles, ensure they are in the same color-palette. This helps make your mantle a great focal point! 
  2. Use smaller Christmas trees. Every house has their main Christmas tree. In addition, you can also purchase smaller, inexpensive, eco-friendly trees to place throughout the home. Decorate these trees with strips of fabric from a T-shirt in holiday colors to save money for the main tree.
  3. Use what you have. Be resourceful. Adding a plate charge and place mat to your everyday dining set adds some jazz to your table. Fresh-cut flowers and candles will help finish the look. You don't need grand, expensive candles -- a little candlelight goes a long way!

As you can see, it doesn't take much to make your home feel more festive. If you have any questions, give us a call or send us an email. We would be happy to help you!

link.title: Prepare Your Home for the Holidays with these Decorating Tips!

entry.title: What Is Most Important When Renovating Your Home in Austin?

Plan Ahead When Renovating

Today, I want to share a video from HGTV to discuss how you can plan ahead when it comes to home renovations. Renovating your home can be an exciting process, but it's important that you don't get ahead of yourself. You can't just go willy-nilly into a major project and expect it to go perfectly. Planning properly for these types of projects can assure a smooth project, and one that may even cost less!

HGTV’s Amy Matthews recommends making a very detailed timeline of your project, including potential things that could go awry and making backup plans in order to prevent these things from happening. Putting your plan onto paper is a good way to start this process.


Another major step is choosing a good team of contractors that you can communicate with. If they don't know what you want done, they can't do it.

Just remember, there is no such thing as too much planning! If you plan on renovating your Austin home, please contact us. We know great contractors and could also give you advice on what projects will bring you the highest return on your investment.

We look forward to hearing from you!

entry.title: And We Could Sell Yours Too!
entry.content:
Want to sell your Austin Home? Get a FREE home value report
Want to buy an Austin Home? Search all homes for sale

The summer home selling season is in the rearview mirror for now, but that doesn't mean the real estate market comes to a screeching halt. People are still buying and selling homes, and I want you to know that you can still do the same.

If you thought that you missed prime-time home selling season, then I'm happy to let you know that you were mistaken. Autumn is a tremendous time to sell your home.

This article from AOL Real Estate offers a full explanation why the fall is a great time to sell, but I'll summarize it for you here. There are two big reasons why now is still a great time to sell.

1. You'll face less competition because most sellers still mistakenly believe that the market comes to a halt at this time of the year. During the spring and summer there are lots of buyers, but there are also a lot of other sellers. This means that in the fall your home will stand out to buyers, and when inventory is low you can also demand more money for your home.

2. Buyers are still in the market, and they're motivated to buy your home. Nobody wants to be buying a home during the holidays, so the prospective buyers we see in the fall are often extremely motivated to buy a home. People who buy in the summer have the luxury of time, but people looking to purchase right now aren't afforded that same luxury. This means that you'll enjoy a smooth and quick sale for a very fair price.

As you can see, it's still a great time to sell your home. Another plus for when you sell right now is that your home probably looks fantastic with all of the fall colors starting to appear. Take this opportunity to snap some high-quality photos so that even if you don't sell now, you have them to market your home with later on in the year.

If you have any questions, please do not hesitate to reach out to us. We look forward to hearing from you!

link.title: And We Could Sell Yours Too!

entry.title: Keep Your Home in Shape for the Summer Selling Season
entry.content:
Want to sell your Austin Home? Get a FREE home value report
Want to buy an Austin Home? Search all homes for sale

I'm here with Gary Sporn from Sporn Inspections. I think Gary is the best at what he does, and today, we'll give you some tips on keeping your home tight during this summer selling season.

One of the main concerns during the summer is rising energy costs. Gary recommends checking the insulation in your attic, and making sure that it is R-30 insulation. That will get you the biggest bang for your buck, and keep the cold air inside. Another thing to do is change your AC filters at least every two months to keep a good air flow through the home.


There are many small things to maintain in your home in order to keep comfortable through the summer. Make sure there is bleach in your primary drain lines at least twice a year, and make sure your exterior weather stripping is secure.

A home is like a car; you need to maintain it in order to avoid costly repairs down the road. When you sell the home, there will be an inspection period, and any and all small problems will be reported to the buyer. Fixing these small things ahead of time can make your home look better in the buyer's eyes.

The most important thing a home inspection does is help the buyer understand the home. A home inspection is well worth the time and money it takes to know all the problems in a home.

Gary has built and remodeled many homes, and learned a lot throughout the process. He enjoys passing that knowledge onto buyers. Between Gary and myself, we have a great list of vendors here in Austin. To contact Gary, call (512) 632-2800.

As always, if you have any questions about today's video, or real estate in general, give me a call or send me an email. I'd be glad to help you.

entry.title: Five Reasons Why Now Is the Perfect Time to Sell in Austin
entry.content:
Want to sell your Austin Home? Get a FREE home value report
Want to buy an Austin Home? Search all homes for sale

Now is a great time to sell your home in Austin. The weather is warm, and the market is hot. I have five major reasons why you should consider selling your home now.

1. Buyer demand is very strong right now. Foot traffic is very high right now, and this means that they are ready, willing, and able to purchase homes.

2. There is much less competition right now.The NAR reported last week that there is a five-month low in inventory, which means if you put your home on the market, you will face less competition. This actually means you can sell quicker and for more money.

3.Home prices are ballooning.This means that you can cash in on a lot of equity. The main reason for the rise in home prices actually has to do with the lack of inventory we're seeing right now.

4.There will never be a better time to move up into a bigger, nicer home. Interest rates are extremely low right now, so this will allow you to purchase a home in a much more affordable manner. Interest rates are hovering right around 4%, but they are projected to rise soon, so now is the time to move up into a nicer home. Just a 1% increase in interest will lower your purchasing power by 10%.

5.It's time to move on with your life.Maybe now is the time to take action and sell your home so that you can do the things that you really want to do in your life. Most people don't sell their homes to make money, they sell to pursue other lifestyle goals.

Hopefully you have found some value in this advice. Right now is truly a great time to sell a home in Austin. There is a lot of demand and very little supply, which means that you are primed to have a good home sale.

If you would like to hear more about the Austin real estate market, please don't hesitate to contact me!

link.title: Five Reasons Why Now Is the Perfect Time to Sell in Austin

entry.title: What Mortgage Changes Do You Need to Know About?
entry.content:
Want to sell your Austin Home? Get a FREE home value report
Want to buy an Austin Home? Search all homes for sale

Today we are excited to be joined by special guest Melanie Taliaferro with the C4 Lending Team at Legacy Mutual Mortgage. Melanie and her crew are the best at what they do. They are super competitive on their rates, and they give exceptional service. They don’t make promises that they can’t keep, which is one of the most important qualities any lender can have.

You have a lot of choices for a lender here in Austin, so why would you choose Melanie and her team? Well, for starters, they aren’t just in the mortgage business, they are in the relationship business. They thrive on repeat clients and referrals, always looking to make the experience as smooth as possible.

Today they are going to share some of the latest news on mortgages, including what’s going on with interest rates and what impending changes are going to switch up the mortgage process.
 
 

We keep hearing from the media that rates are going to rise soon. They have already crept up a little bit, but are still hovering in the 3-4% range. There are so many different things that go into determining the kind of rate you qualify for, so it’s hard to get an accurate snapshot of rates even by researching it. What we do know is this: we are still hovering around all-time lows for interest rates and are happy to be there for the time being. 
 
One change that you need to know about has to do with lending guidelines and the CFPB. Changes are coming that will ultimately make the mortgage process run smoother, but they could cause a little delay in the process. You probably won’t see as many 30-day closings as you are used to.

If you’re thinking about buying a home, know that this deadline could affect your mortgage process and if you buy before they happen, on October 3rd, you can avoid them. If you’ve got any questions, you can always reach out to us via phone or email. Talk to you soon!

link.title: What Mortgage Changes Do You Need to Know About?

There are a lot of real estate teams in Austin, but what makes our team different? What do we do better than everyone else?

First off, you should know that we work mainly by referrals. This means that we're not spending time marketing ourselves as a brand; we devote our time to marketing and selling your home. This also prevents us from charging you with excessive marketing fees.

We're also a very honest team. We won't be coming up to your home in suits and ties because we're not concerned about our appearance. We're more concerned about buying and selling homes for our clients.

What we can also do is create a custom marketing plan for your home. We know that every home is different and that each one has different selling points. This is why your home needs a custom plan in order to find the right buyers who are willing to pay top dollar.

We're also backed by Keller Williams Realty, the largest and best real estate company in the nation. So, if you're selling your home in Austin and moving elsewhere, we have a huge network of agents that we can refer you to.

Whether you're trying to buy or sell, or if you know someone who is trying to do so, please don't hesitate to call me. I would love the opportunity to speak with you or anyone you know.

Always refer to me as your #1 resource for real estate in Austin!

entry.title: What Is Happening with Closing Periods in Austin?
entry.content:
Want to sell your Austin Home? Get a FREE home value report
Want to buy an Austin Home? Search all homes for sale

Today we're going to be talking about some big changes that are coming to the closing period. Currently, the earliest you can expect to close is about 30 days. This is the point in time from when the buyer and seller agree on a contract, to when you get your keys. 

Unless you're using a good agent and a rock star lender, you will likely not close in less than 30-45 days. It's just kind of an industry standard, and has been for a long time. There is just a lot of stuff that happens in this time period, like inspections, appraisals, title searches, etc.


However, the Consumer Finance Protection Bureau (CFPB) is about to change all of this. On August 1 of this year, they have new regulations coming out that will affect your ability to close on time, and it will affect everyone involved in your transaction. 

If you want to buy a home this year, I advise you to do so before August 1, as it will likely slow your transaction. If you need help buying a home before then, I urge you to get into contact with me now.

I'm always willing to help you with any of your buying or selling needs in Austin, so don't hesitate to reach out to me.

link.title: What Is Happening with Closing Periods in Austin?

entry.title: How to Win Against Multiple Offers Every Time
entry.content:
Want to sell your Austin Home? Get a FREE home value report
Want to buy an Austin Home? Search all homes for sale

We're seeing an extremely hot market here in Austin, and if you're buying a home you're probably going to need some help when making an offer. There is a lot of competition right now and multiple offers are common, so your offer needs to be enticing. It also needs to be reasonable so you're not overpaying on a home.

  1. Have your pre-qualification letter ready to go when you submit your offer. If you're not able to prove that you can afford the home, you're simply going to be passed over. Furthermore, having a pre-qualification is almost a requirement, especially when the market is this competitive. 
  2. Remember that money talks, and most sellers in this market are simply looking to make the highest net profits. Sit down with your agent and come up with the best possible price on the home, and know that if your offer doesn't get accepted, then you gave it your best shot and didn't overpay for a home. 
  3. Consult with the seller to form an ideal closing date. It's always important to consult with the seller, because if you can be the most flexible buyer, then you may have the upper hand on all of the other buyers. 
  4. Shorten your inspection period: Customarily if a buyer backs out of a sale during this period, they can get their earnest money back, so this is why sellers would like this time period to be as short as possible. Some buyers would even forfeit this option, but I'd consult with your real estate agent before doing this.
  5. Write a personalized letter to the seller. This can often be a great emotional appeal to the seller, and homeowners are always more comfortable selling to someone that they know will take good care of the property. Sellers really appreciate this on the part of the buyer, and this could be a small step that could move you to the front of the line.

Hopefully these tips can help you to buy the home of your dreams, and if you need any help buying or selling a home in Austin this year, please don't hesitate to contact me.

link.title: How to Win Against Multiple Offers Every Time

entry.title: Is It Easier to Sell Vacated Homes in Austin?
entry.content:
Want to sell your Austin Home? Get a FREE home value report
Want to buy an Austin Home? Search all homes for sale
 
We're often asked by sellers whether or not they need to vacate their home during a sale. The answer to this question will not always be the same, and there are a few things to consider in order to find an appropriate solution to this problem. Buyers have different reactions to homes that are staged and homes that are vacant.

Overall, the more accessible your home is, the better, and this is what makes vacant homes easy to show. This doesn't mean that they're also easy to sell, though.

Do you have pets? If so, then you may want to move out of the home while you're trying to sell it. Odors and stains left by pets can really turn buyers away, and the same goes for if you have young children in the home. Animals and pets can make it difficult to show your home on short notice, and they can be distractions to potential buyers.

Then again, vacant homes are sometimes a turn off for buyers. Occasionally vacant homes can feel smaller than they really are, and some buyers like to see homes that are lived in so that they can get an idea of what they might be able to do with the property. 

If you have any questions or concerns about this issue, please don't hesitate to contact me. I'm always here to help you!

link.title: Is It Easier to Sell Vacated Homes in Austin?

entry.title: Austin Real Estate Market Update
entry.content:
Want to sell your Austin Home? Get a FREE home value report
Want to buy an Austin Home? Search all homes for sale

Today I'll be updating you on the Austin real estate market. A lot of people have been wondering whether we're seeing a buyer's market or a seller's market. Inventory is slightly low (we have a 4-month supply of homes), so we're actually situated in a seller's market. 

Inventory is especially low in North Austin in places like Georgetown, Cedar Park, and Leander. There are a lot of bidding wars, and there simply aren't enough homes in our area to keep up with the demand that we're seeing.

Furthermore, interest rates are sitting at historic lows, so there has never been a better time to go out and get a mortgage. If you're buying a home, you need to have a pre-qualification, because having a pre-approval or a pre-qualification will make you stand out in this competitive market. 

For sellers, right now is an absolutely ideal time to sell your home. We're seeing multiple offers, and homes in all price ranges are going for top dollar.

If you need any assistance buying or selling in Austin, please don't hesitate to contact me!

link.title: Austin Real Estate Market Update
